content.description: Start sitting at deep pockets at the left side of the white streak. Climb up and right into the scoop, then follow good holds around the bulge.
content.protection: Pads, spotter. Watch out for the boulder behind you.
content.location: On the Plaque Wall behind Triangle Boulder. Starts in the left part of the white streak, climbs up and right. Walk off to the left.

content.description: A fun and very easy traverse on a boulder right of the Triangle. Climb from left to right along the huge huecos to a slightly more difficult move to jugs on the lip and top out. Several eliminates are possible. This is a good place to take beginner climbers.
content.protection: A pad if you'd like, the landing is great.
content.location: On a big boulder a few yards right of the Triangle/Microdots area. Climb left to right.

content.description: Traverse either direction on the vertical front face of the Triangle Boulder, staying below the lip (usually done right to left, I prefer this direction because you can top out on the V0 arete.) Crux is near the middle where the hands thin out and everything seems to be facing the wrong way. There are quite a few options for sequences.
content.protection: Pads optional depending on how high you decide to go.

content.description: Start far back and right throw a heel at the start and come into the pocket seam. Follow the seam until you  make a big throw and then have to turn around and drop in. top out where moab ends.
content.location: To the left of the triangle boulder on the hill out of sight. If you're standing right in front of the triangle boulder take a left towards money shot and continue to look up right until you find a bigger roof. If you hit streetfighter you have gone too far.

content.description: Self-induced vomiting is a good highball that stands alone across the road from the Triangle Boulder. Climb up to the bulge and cut loose from the skirt with some good pockets. Move into some undercling pockets and slap for the horizontal break above. Easy top-out.
content.location: Across the road from the Triangle.

content.description: Basically one move, but it's a hard one. Pull on to two good pockets and throw for the sloping hueco. Another short pull gains a large jug. Top out.
content.location: Plaque Wall, directly to the right of the plaque.
Far left side of the wall.

content.description: Start sitting matched on two huge pockets. Trend right around the arete and make a huge toss to a good right hand rail (or use an intermediate) and climb up good holds to the top.
content.location: The right arete of the plaque wall.

content.description:
The rounded boulders a few yards right of the Triangle Boulder hold some surprisingly fun lines, the best being a traverse that starts on a jug at the left, traverses right through the diagonal seam, and tops out on the right boulder. There are also some quality vertical lines on these boulders, along with some neat eliminates. 

  (I think these are the boulders referred to as "Microdots" in Toula's A Cheap Way to Fly, but I'm not 100% sure.)
content.protection: Pad and spotter if you like. Good landing and not very tall.
content.location: A bit to the right of the Triangle Boulder, you'll find two round/egg-shaped boulders. Have fun.

content.description: The first move is the crux. Start low on good pockets and figure out how to crank to the good left crimp below the scoop, then cross through and get situated in the scoop to top out on big holds. Lots of fun once you unlock the moves.
content.protection: Pad, spotter. Beware the boulder behind you.
content.location: On the Plaque Wall behind Triangle Boulder, climbs right of the wide white streak. Walk off to the right.

content.description:
Longish horizontal roof. Start on left in a small slot, move right and top out wherever you can! 

  Seems like there are a couple ways to do this, reachy or burly. Maybe a campus move in there somewhere. 

  Not sure why this hasn't been added yet or if it should be in a new area? All the stuff around triangle is a bit confusing.
content.protection: Traverses, two pads is fine but falling off the topout could be kind of a bummer.
content.location: Walk to triangle boulder and follow the trail straight left for about 100 yards. Small trail branches off and switchbacks up the hill to the right.

content.description: Climb the high arête on the left side of the Triangle Boulder with jugs and those cool slot-pockets.
content.protection: Spotter and pad. It's easy, but a fall from the top could be unpleasant.

content.description: Start low matched on a sidepull and move past a funky crimp to better holds. Short, but fingery and fun.
content.protection: A pad is nice, a spotter wouldn't hurt either.
content.location: On the Plaque Wall, this is the first line to the left of the white streak with scoop.

content.description:
This is a line that may have always been there but was mostly hiding behind a healthy Ponderosa Pine. A few seasons ago someone decided that they would test their tree cutting skills and remove the growing Ponderosa from the area.  

  The remaining problem is good enough but a better reminder that taking development to this sort of level is lame and will make you a Douchbag Lumberjack.  

  If anyone wants to step up and mention the real name of this problem, go for it!
content.location: Around left side of Triangle Boulder. Look for where the tree once stood then climb up from there.

content.description: Climb the holds found in the black streak on the front face of the triangle.  Big holds on the top.
Squat start and use the two holes. Some pretty good holds going up and only one small hard move but you can trust your feet. Finish the route too the left of the tree at the top.
content.protection: Have a pad and a spotter.
content.location: Left of the Plaque. There are two holds about eye height that you can start on. Top out left of the small tree at the top.

content.description:
This boulder will let you know that in fact you aren't lost on some AZ back road. 

  It also has some great lines on it. Pick your own adventure in general the farther left you go the harder the line and the scarier the top-out. 

  Right behind this boulder in the same area is the place where one of the developers of AZ climbing met his unfortunate and untimely end, there is a plaque in commemoration.
